They came with would-be gravity — and led</br>A helpless being guarded all around;</br>And then they bar'd unto the sun, his head,</br>And bound him fierce and tightly to the ground—</br>No groan escap'd him — not a word or sound,</br>Save a soft sigh his heaving breast upsent;</br>He was all calmness — and tho' tightly bound,</br>His hands he wrung not, nor his grey hairs rent,</br>But with devoted look, to Heaven a pray'r he sent.

High was the pile around him — still he sate</br>Serene and grave — no angry glance gave he—</br>Fierce gaz'd the monks — yet he, sublimely great.</br>Look'd to the moment when he should be free</br>From earthly toils, and earthly vanity,</br>Without a sigh — he pitied those who burn'd</br>With inward rage; and his sincerity</br>With hatred direful, inhuman spurn'd,</br>And now their vengeful eyes, in menace to him turn'd.

"Wilt thou recant?" cried one with eye of fire,</br>"Wilt thou throw off thy vile religion — seek</br>From the blest virgin a more pure attire</br>Than thine own curs'd habiliments?" his cheek</br>Nor blanch'd, nor flush'd — nor essay'd he to speak</br>But his wan eye was lighted with a lay</br>Divinely given; yet 'twas humble — meek—</br>Now it was upward turn'd, as if to say</br>This is on earth my last, but yet most glorious day!

They look'd with wonder! — but a moment gaz'd—</br>For now the torch was lighted, and the pile</br>By the breeze puffed, up toward Heaven blaz'd,</br>Yet he, the suff'rer, calmly sat the while,</br>And o'er his face there beam'd a blissful smile.</br>Now stretching forth his arms, he ardent cried,</br>"Forgive them, Father; let them not revile</br>Thy name again; but ope conviction's tide"—</br>Then with a deep drawn sigh, the humble Martyr died.</br>
